elementSpec.desc: Limits and defines values of the attribute place in add. Beta maṣāḥǝft Guidelines

valItem.desc: text written above the line
text written below the line
text written at the foot of the page
text written within the body of the text
text written between two lines
text written to the left of the preceding text node
text written in the margin (left, right, or both)
text written both on top and left or right and bottom
text written on the opposite, i.e. facing, page
text written on the other side of the leaf
text written over previously deleted text
text written to the right of the preceding text node
text written at the top of the page
use this only when no information is currently available and make yourself a note to check photos or source to improve this point
Age, the value should be given in a @dur attribute according to W3C datatypes
Duration of a reign, the value should be given in a @dur attribute according to W3C datatypes
Duration of life, the value should be given in a @dur attribute according to W3C datatypes
Duration of marriage, the value should be given in a @dur attribute according to W3C datatypes
Generic duration, the value should be given in a @dur attribute according to W3C datatypes
Date of foundation
Date of the composition of a work
Date of the translation of a work
Date of the revision of a work
Date of the composition of a specific recension
Date of a saint’s martyrdom
Date of birth (do not use this in a person record, use element birth)
Date of a person’s ascension to power
Date of death
The date of production of the document (EMA)
If the commemoration is repeated, please add this value as well in type
ʿĀmata ʿālam, ʿĀmat ʾəm-fəṭrat, ʿĀmat ʾəm-ʾAddām, ʿĀmata məḥrat (=Era of the World)
ʿĀmata śəggāwe, ʿĀmata məḥrat (Era of the Incarnation/ Ethiopian contemporary Calendar of the contemporary time, year 1 = 7/8 CE)
ʿĀmata məḥrat (= Ethiopian Era of Grace, year 1 = 359/360 CE)
ʿĀmata samāʿtāt (Era of Martyrs/ Era of Diocletian, year 1 = 283/284 CE)
ʿĀmata ʾƎskəndər (= Era of Alexander of Macedon, year 1 = 319 BC)
Evangelist's name associated with the year (repeated in the canonical order: Matthew, Mark, Luke, John)
Gregorian calendar. Only for use in IslHornAfr project records
Only for use in IslHornAfr project records
ʿĀmata ʾagār (= Hiǧrī, Islamic Era)
Julian calendar
Year from the Creation
ʿĀmata qamar (= Year of the 532 year cycle, can correspond to the ʿĀmata samāʿtāt with year 1 = 283/284 CE or the true ʿĀmata məḥrat, with year 1 = 359/360 CE)
records with this type represent an ethnic group as a whole and in general

sch:rule.sch:report: For an exact date, please use @when.

sch:rule.sch:report: Please, don't use @from and @to in citedRange, write the range into the element

An Empty citedRange is not allowed, remove it if you don't need it or please enter the page range, unit number according to need and use @unit to specifiy the type of range. Multiple citedRange are allowed.

works not universally recognised in the Christian and Jewish religions as belonging to the fixed set of canonical scriptures, either for reasons of tradition or of secondary development or doubtful authorship or heterodox opinions and for this rejected from one or the other biblical canon of the respective tradition: e.g. the Book of Enoch, Jubilees, Herma, the Miracles of Mary, the Miracles of Jesus, Maṣḥafa ṭomār, the apocryphal Acts of the Apostles, etcSee Apocrypha in Beta maṣāḥǝft
biblical books belonging to the New Testament. See NewTestament in Beta maṣāḥǝft
biblical books belonging to the Old Testament. See OldTestament in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works belonging to the biblical canon, subdivided into the Old and New Testament. See Bible in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing the description of the life events of an individual. See Biography in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing regulations for the government of the Christian organizations, e.g., the Sinodos, the Fətḥa Nagaśt, the Śərʿata faws manfasāwi. See CanonLaw in Beta maṣāḥǝft
any works of Tigrinya literature See TigrinyaLiterature in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing fiction. See Fiction in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing a translation. See Translation in Beta maṣāḥǝft
any works of Amharic literature See AmharicLiterature in Beta maṣāḥǝft
any works of Beta ʾƎsrāʾel literature See BetaEsraelLiterature in Beta maṣāḥǝft
any works belonging to the Christian tradition See ChristianLiterature in Beta maṣāḥǝft

Genre of literature whose aims were the veneration of the saint and the creation of an ideal of Christian behavior as well as documentation and entertainment. As a portrayal of historical personages, hagiography overlaps with historiography, conveying historical information, using chronicles as sources, and, in turn, serving as a source for chronicles; as an edifying genre, hagiography may bear resemblance to the Sermon. Three major types of hagiography already existed in the early centuries of the Roman empire: Martyrion, the account of a martyr's trial and execution; Vita, a saint's biography; and Apophthegmata Patrum, a collection of wise sayings of hermits. Probably by the 7th c. the description of posthumous Miracles was established as a separate genre. See Hagiography in Beta maṣāḥǝft

works containing land grants, Amharic historical works of the 19th century which cannot be labelled chronicles, the history of churches and monasteries, biographies etc. See HistoryAndHistoriography in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing royal and other chronicles e.g., Tārik za-Walda ʿAmid, Zenā ʾAyhud and various treatises of Ethiopian history. See Chronicles in Beta maṣāḥǝft

works and collections of works containing homiletic texts to be read on the occasion of specific commemorative days, e.g., the homiliaries in honour of Michael and Gabriel, Dərsāna sanbata krəstiyān, Dərsān māḥyāwi, Dərsāna madḫāna ʿālam, etc. See Homily in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing texts of Islamic subject. See IslamicLiterature in Beta maṣāḥǝft
manuscripts containing the Koran. See Koran in Beta maṣāḥǝft
texts that formally record grants and rights to institutions and individuals, such as land charters, donation acts, land grants. See LegalDocument in Beta maṣāḥǝft
texts of epistolary genre with an independent support. See Letter in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing directives for the liturgy of the office services (except for the mass and rituals like weddings and funerals), e.g., Maṣḥafa nəfq, the Horologium, etc. See Liturgy in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing scriptural readings to be read on various religious occasions (fast, feasts, liturgical periods), e.g. Maṣḥafa gəṣṣəw, Maṣḥafa ʾaśləti, etc. See Lectionary in Beta maṣāḥǝft
See Rituals and Rites. See Rituals in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing directives for the celebration of religious offices such as weddings and funerals, e.g., Maṣḥafa taklil and Maṣḥafa gənzat. See RitualsAndRites in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing liturgical instructions for the celebration of the mass, e.g. Maṣḥafa qəddāse. See Missal in Beta maṣāḥǝft

works containing magic texts, prayers and formulas to be recited or carried along for healing and as a protection from demons, diseases and natural accidents, e.g. Maftəḥe śərāy, etc. See Magic in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing medical texts and recipes for healing. See Medicine in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing texts of various unspecified nature. See Miscellanea in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing texts to be read for the education and edification of the monastic community members, e.g., Mār Yəsḥāq, Filkəsyos, ʾAragāwi manfasāwi, etc. See MonasticLiterature in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing observations and investigations into a number of natural phenomena. See NaturalSciences in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works belonging to other literary genres. See Other in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing praises, ʿarke-hymns, salām-hymns, malkəʾ, songs and canticles, texts subdivided into stanzas, rhymed texts. See Poetry in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing prayers, supplications and invocations to God and other revered entities. See Prayers in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works of qǝne poetry, such as those marked as ʿǝṭāna mogar or mawaddǝsSee Qene in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing philosophical texts and sentences, as Maṣḥafa falāsfā ṭabibān. See Philosophy in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing patristic texts dealing with theological subjects, e.g. Qerəllos, Hāymānota ʾAbaw, the Five Pillars of Mystery, etc. See Theology in Beta maṣāḥǝft
exegetical works containing the interpretation of biblical texts, e.g, the Tərgʷāme and ʾAndəmtā corpus. See Commentary in Beta maṣāḥǝft
works containing texts for the calculation of the moveable feasts and for other calendrical computes, e.g., ʾAbušākər, Bāḥra ḥassāb. See Chronography in Beta maṣāḥǝft

A particular type of a manuscript - usually a main copy of the Four Gospels of a church - where documents (land charters, foundation charters, etc) concerning the place are collected. See GoldenGospel in Beta maṣāḥǝft
A particular type of a manuscript made only of miniaturesSee miniature collection in Beta maṣāḥǝft
Items belonging to the Christian tradition which do not contain text, such as miniature collections. See ChristianContent in Beta maṣāḥǝft
Sometimes developed, with the formalized incipit and explicit, sometimes nothing more than a short string of hidden God’s names, written in a crude hand. See Asmat in Beta maṣāḥǝft
Works belonging to apocalyptic literature. See ApocalypticLiterature in Beta maṣāḥǝft
Works used in the system of traditional education as didactic material. See Didactic Material in Beta maṣāḥǝft
Research in Ethiopian and Eritrean studies. See Study in Beta maṣāḥǝft

sch:rule.sch:report: title in a Work entity must always have an @xml:id which identifies alternative titles or a @corresp pointing to one of such xml:ids. Format of the id should be like t1 t2, etc. and thus in @corresp #t1, #t2, etc.

valItem.desc: the work is contained completely in the manuscript
the work is contained incompletely in the manuscript, i.e. even only a small part is missing
Transliteration of the title
IHA transliteration
Only used by IHA project
Only used by IHA project
Only used by IHA project
syriaca.org: an existing print catalogue provides a descriptive title
syriaca.org: a title for such work established by the editor or cataloguer
for titleStmt, specifies to which title to give priority in output.
EMA
EMA
EMA
EMA
entreat to God for help. Examples: Beta maṣāḥǝft Xpath search for //t:title[contains(@subtype,'supplication')]
contains the title, tafaṣṣama/malʾa and further information. Examples: Beta maṣāḥǝft Xpath search for //t:title[contains(@subtype,'expanded')]
is used for a title occurring at the beginning of a work. Examples: Beta maṣāḥǝft Xpath search for //t:title[contains(@subtype,'inscriptio')]
for a title occurring at the end of a work. Examples: Beta maṣāḥǝft Xpath search for //t:title[contains(@subtype,'subscriptio')]
for a title copied together with the text. Examples: Beta maṣāḥǝft Xpath search for //t:title[contains(@subtype,'embedded')]
to signal that the title is only of a translation. Examples: Beta maṣāḥǝft Xpath search for //t:title[contains(@subtype,'translation')]

Editions of the work
ID of the work in an external clavis (CC, CPG etc.)
Modern translations of the work
Secondary bibliography on the subject of the record
Relations between the subject of the record and other entities (persons, related works, manuscript filiation etc.)
Ruler of a country, region or similar
Military occupation
Occupation within an academic institution or independently pursuing academic interests

Literary activities (i.e. author, translator)

Other occupation
to be used for places and institutions
to be used in binding description
for use in binding description
note stating that the manuscript has been donated to an individual or to an institution.
note stating the book belongs to an individual or to an institution.
note stating that the book has been purchased for money by an individual or an institution.
note stating that the manuscript has been generically acquired by an individual or an institution. Similar to “PurchaseNote”.
note written down as a receipt of a transaction of goods.
note admonishing individuals to a righteous behavior. See also “Exhortation”.
note stating the concession of lands by an authority in favor of individuals or typically of institutions.
act of foundation of an institution.
note containing the spiritual genealogy of the leader of the community or an institution, or the family members of an individual.
scribe’s signature.
entreat to God for help, written down in a later hand.
note added at the end of the main text concerning its completion.
hymn or praise to God or other entities.
note addressed to the brethren in order to commemorate a saint, to celebrate a given feast or for educational purposes.
invocation against those who stole or erased the book or against other individuals. Not very different from “Condemnation”.
list of books or items held by the individual or the institution.
note stating a transaction of goods between individuals or institutions.
scribe’s note on commencing the work
scribe’s note on ordering of the copying
scribe’s note on commissioning of the writing
scribe’s note on completing the writing
scribe’s note on assigning of land.
scribe’s note on bequeathing.
documentary record concerning a reconciliation.
documentary record concerning a litigation.
documentary record concerning a transaction of goods.
documentary record concerning the distribution of goods or lands.
documentary record concerning the guarantors of a transaction or a loan.
generic note of a documentary, official character.
scribe’s entreat to God.
note whose content is hardly understandable.
list of the guarantors of transaction or a loan.
commemorative notice on a saint. Mainly taken from the Synaxarion.
note condemning those who stole the book or erased it.
prayer to be read or carried along for protective purposes.
note containing a generic poetic text. See “PoemArke”, “PoemQene”, “PoemSalam”.
rhymed composition fulfilling the requirements of the Qəne-hymn.
short rhymed poem beginning with the words “salām (ʾəbəl) la-”.
five-line rhymed poem.
stamp affixed by the owning institution, e.g., a library.
note for calculating the moveable feasts and for other calendrical computes.
fragment of a literary work added at a later stage to a manuscript. See also “GuestText”.
communication formally addressed to an individual or an institution.
set form of words to be recited or carried along for healing and protecting.
elaborate note to be recited or carried along for healing and protecting.
note added at a later stage in order to comment word or passages of the main text. See also “Gloss”.
note added at a later stage in order to correct words or passages of the main text.
note added at a later stage in order to interpret or explain words or passages of the main text. See also “Comment”.
note excommunicating an individual from a religious community, e.g., a monastery.
a complete work, provided with its own ID, added later to a manuscript.

The hymn of composed of some 50 stanzas, describing the “limbs” of a saint (but there are also Malkeʾ for the Trinity, Covenant of Mercy, Jesus, St. Mary, even for literary works, icons etc.). Malke Hymn

Mostly in Amharic; usually addressed to the ministers as to how the texts should be read or how the church service/liturgy be carried out. Technical directives only, other formulas. The words በል, አንብ are frequently included. Directive
Sometimes developed, with the formalized incipit and explicit, sometimes nothing more than a short string of “hidden God’s names”, written in a crude hand. Asmat
Rare, but important records explaining the local customary law. Usually in Amharic, difficult to understand. Customary Law
Regulations, statutes, constitutions of the churches; monastic rules. Statutes
Notes difficult to classify. Mixed Note
Finding Aids in the text (legacy from Ethio-SPaRe).

sch:rule.sch:report: ab in layout should always have a type and optionally a subtype

ab in note is used in listPlace for institutions and should always have a @type equal to 'history' or 'description'. @type equal to 'appellation' can be used to list a series of ways in which a place is called.
Dividers must have ids starting with 'div' followed by a progressive number, e.g. div1, div2, div3
an ab[@type='appellation'] must contain a list.
seg in layout should always have a type

valItem.desc: to qualify expressions as tafaṣṣama/malʾa.
entreat to God for help.
contains the title, tafaṣṣama/malʾa and further information.
is used for a title occurring at the beginning of a work
for a title occurring at the end of a work
for a title copied together with the text.
to signal that the title is only of a translation

sch:rule.sch:report: DecoNotes must have ids starting with the letter 'd' followed by a progressive number, e.g. d1, d2, d3
DecoNotes in Binding Description must have ids starting with the letter 'b' followed by a progressive number, e.g. b1, b2, b3

valItem.desc: Under the turn-ins. The pastedown is pasted under the turn-ins.
Over the turn-ins. The pastedown is pasted over the turn-ins.
Left pastedown, on the upper board.
Right pastedown, on the lower board.
an ornament around the page
An independent illustration in colour that occupies the full-page or part of the equivalent space of one or more columns of text.
A border that surrounds a text or image and may occupy the margins and intercolumnar space. Typically used to mark the beginning of a new text or section of text.

A decorative border that surrounds a text and may occupy the margins and intercolumnar space. Typically used to mark the beginning of a new text or section of text. With two specifications, for Band (single border) and Frame (border encompassing multiple sides of text)
Decorative frame encompassing all four sides of the text and may occupy the margins and intercolumnar space. Typically used to mark the beginning of a new text or section of text.
Single decorative border that surrounds a text and may occupy the margins and intercolumnar space. Typically used to mark the beginning of a new text or section of text.
crude drawings which do not belong to the primary strata of the manuscript (already encoded as “extras”)
A monochrome or bichrome image that is not painted.
A drawing that conveys information or knowledge in schematic form.
An enlarged letter at the beginning of a text of paragraph that features figurative or decorative motifs.
A small miniature painted next to one of the margins of the text.
An image on paper created with a printing plate.
A printed image, usually of devotional character, glued to a manuscript
to be used in binding description
to be used in binding description
to be used in binding description
to be used in binding description
to be used in binding description
to be used in binding description
to be used in binding description
to be used in binding description
to be used in binding description. Materials of which the binding is made.
to be used in binding description. Endband at the head end of the spine of a book.
for use in binding description. Endband at the tail end of the spine of a book.

for use in binding description. Structural and decorative elements of the binding which are found at the head and tail of the spine of a book. The ethiopian endbands are usually slit-braid stripes of leather or link-stitch sewings.
for use in binding description. Stripe of different form and material used to keep closed a book. Traces of fastenings can be holes and pins on the outer edge of the boards.
for use in binding description. The part of the book opposite the fore-edge.
for use in binding description. Portable leather case with attached slip where the manuscript is kept.
for use in binding description. Components made from one or more pieces of material (usually wood) used to protect and support a bookblock.
for use in binding description. Sewing stations are created by passing a thread through a spine fold when sewing a book.
for use in binding description. All the leaves found at each side of a bookblock, intended to give protection to the text leaves.
The material that constitutes the immediate covering of the completed binding.

sch:rule.sch:report: Manuscript parts ids must start with the letter 'p' followed by a progressive number, e.g. p1, p1.3, p1.1_i1.1

The Underscore is used in ids to mark a nesting of differnt ids, especially items in parts. there should thus be only one of them as a maximum. If you have parts into parts or items into items, please use a full stop. p1.2_i3.4 is e.g. the subitem 4 of item 3 in subpart 2 of part 1.

Content Items in Manuscript parts must have ids starting with the reference to the part in which they are contained, then underscore and the letter 'i' followed by a progressive number, e.g. p1.1_i1.1, p1.1_i2.

The Underscore is used in ids to mark a nesting of differnt ids, especially items in parts. there should thus be only one of them as a maximum. If you have parts into parts or items into items, please use a full stop. p1.2_i3.4 is e.g. the subitem 4 of item 3 in subpart 2 of part 1.
Colophon in Manuscript items must have ids starting with coloph.
HandNotes must have ids starting with the letter 'h' followed by a progressive number, e.g. h1, h2, h3

sch:rule.sch:report: A persName in a mss, place or work description should always contain an attribute @ref pointing to the relevant record

valItem.desc: the illustrator of the manuscript
the copyist of the manuscript
the person who donated the manuscript
the author of a work
the translator of a work
manuscript binder
parchment maker
the owner of a ms or an item
the commissioner of a ms or an item
the saint to whom the tabot is dedicated
the person paying for a ms (possibly not the same as donor/commissioner)
the normalized transcription of the name in fidal
name given at birth
name given at birth
name given at baptism
name given on coronation (kings but also patriarchs)
name given on entering monastic life
the name of the battle horse of kings and rulers
a name given to a person associated to his occupation or other deeds
nom de guerre (if different from horse name, e.g. Malas)
short form (diminutive or abbreviated, e.g. Taklo for Takla Maryam)
father's name, esp. for eventual Russian names, but could be also highlighted in others
alternative name
the saint to whom the tābot is dedicated

sch:rule.sch:report: A placeName in a mss, person or work description should always contain an attribute @ref pointing to the relevant record
At least the first objectDesc of msDesc must have attribute form specified.

valItem.desc: manuscript format consisting of quires bound together to the spine, in their turn made up of a variable number of leaves sewn together and protected by two hard boards.
manuscript format consisting of one continuous flow of writing material rolled up, generally around one or two wooden cylindrical supports.
manuscript format consisting of one leaf assembled in a multiple zig-zag folding, resembling an accordion, and generally enclosed between two hard boards.
manuscript format consisting of one single unbound sheet.
other manuscript formats.
A printed book.
A phootograph.
An inscribed object different from a codex, scroll or leaf
An object consisting of an industrially produced paperblock in the form of a notebook.
A so called peacock-shaped parchment manuscript, folded as a fan.

sch:rule.sch:report: a relation element is only allowed within a listRelation (for places, institution, person and groups) or in a listBibl[@type='relations'] in manuscripts and works

valItem.desc: @active: Person, @passive: Person. http://data.snapdrgn.net/ontology/snap#MotherOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. http://data.snapdrgn.net/ontology/snap#NephewOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. http://data.snapdrgn.net/ontology/snap#NieceOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. http://data.snapdrgn.net/ontology/snap#SiblingOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. http://data.snapdrgn.net/ontology/snap#SisterOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. http://data.snapdrgn.net/ontology/snap#SonOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. http://data.snapdrgn.net/ontology/snap#SiblingOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. http://data.snapdrgn.net/ontology/snap#UncleOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.

@active: PersonGroup, @passive: Person. ATTENTION! A person Group! This is used for example for monastic groups. http://d-nb.info/standards/elementset/agrelon.owl#hasFounder Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: PersonGroup, @passive: Person. ATTENTION! A person Group! This is used for example for monastic groups. http://xmlns.com/foaf/spec/#term_member Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Work. http://erlangen-crm.org/current/P129i_is_subject_of Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Work. http://purl.org/saws/ontology#isAttributedAuthorOf Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.

@active: Person, @passive: Work. The subject of the relation is author of a translation of a work in another language and there is no digital resource enabling us to document the authorship of this work and the fact that the work as such is a translation of another work. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Place, @passive: Place. http://www.geonames.org/ontology#nearby Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Place, @passive: Place. http://www.geonames.org/ontology#locatedIn Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.

@active: Place, @passive: Place. A related resource. Dublin Core relation Please use only if no other relation fits, and consider searching for a better option and suggesting that relation instead. This is now only suggested for those cases of unspecified relation between two places.
@active: Person, @passive: Place. But note the literary specification. definition in syriaca.org Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Person, @passive: Place. This person has a Tābot at the location... Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Work, @passive: Manuscript. or @active: Person, @passive: Work. or @active: Place, @passive: Work. http://lawd.info/ontology/hasAttestation Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Work ArtTheme, @passive: Work Person Place http://erlangen-crm.org/current/P129_is_about Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
@active: Work ArtTheme, @passive: Work. http://purl.org/saws/ontology#contains Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. States that one or more identified discontinuities constitute a UniProd, which can be certain or hypothetical. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. States that a UniCirc or a UniProd contains the Units declared in the object passive. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. The Unit has one of the possible model for its class. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. Something happens to a UniCirc or less often a UniProd. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. Something happens to a UniCirc or less often a UniProd. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. If the model of the transformation is multiple, you can specify which individual parts constitute it. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. If the model of the transformation is simple, you can specify of which individual multiple transformation it is a part. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. A transformation produces new UniProds. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. A transformation results in a new UniProd or a new UniCirc. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. Certain or Hypothetique. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. Declares for a UniCirc one or more of the Stratum types in Andrist 2015, 512. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. Declares one or more of the Stratum types in Andrist 2015, 512 and assign them to a UniCirc. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.

Use for stratigraphic description. might be used to locate a unit defined relationally. If stated, a further relation is needed with one of the properties defining the locus. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. the locus range starts at. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. the locus range ends at. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for stratigraphic description. the locus has target. Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Fine for everything, especially to match with external entities. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exactMatch Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Fine for everything, especially to match with external entities. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#broadMatch Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Fine for everything, especially to match with external entities. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#closeMatch Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.

Fine for every Authority File, especially to match with external SKOS vocabularies, e.g. Ligatus. Assumes this is a skos:Concept. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#broader Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.

@active: Place Person, @passive: Dillmann lexicon entry. corresponds to the lemma ... (associates a Dillmann Online Lexicon Linguae Aethiopicae person name to the person record in the subject). Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.
Use for complex descriptions of Manuscripts or Works, passive should be an integer. http://erlangen-crm.org/efrbroo/CLP57_should_have_number_of_parts Beta maṣāḥǝft SPARQL query for examples.

sch:rule.sch:report: the outermost div must always have an attribute type edition, bibliography, commentary, translation or apparatus; type textpart is to be used inside edition.

valItem.desc: to contain apparatus criticus or textual notes
to contain bibliographical information, previous publications, etc.
to contain all editorial commentary, historical/prosopographical discussion, etc.
to contain the text of the edition itself; may include multiple text-parts
used to divide a div[type=edition] into multiple parts (fragments, columns, faces, etc.)
to contain a translation of the text into one or more modern languages
this container is for a book and may contain chapters
this container is for a chapter and may contain sections
this container is for a stanza and may contain verses
incipit of the text
explicit of the text
to be used for canonical texts like LIT2688CanonsNicaea2

sch:rule.sch:report: Each record must have a type with one of the values suggested.

attDef.desc: For Manuscripts e.g. EMML2312 ES15 (Ethio-SPaRe) BLadd100 (British Library, fondo, numero) BNFabb3 (Bibliotheque nationale de France, fondo, numero) Works = LIT1001Homili (LIT + incremental number + first world of title) Places = LOC2969Ensala (LOC + incremental number + first world of place name) People = PRS1001AbbaTam (PRS + incremental number + first world of name) Institutions = INS0030Addaqaharsi (INS + 4 digit number + first world of name)

valItem.desc: Description of a Manuscript
Description of a Person
Description of a generic place
Description of an institution where manuscripts are preserved
Description of a recognizable literary or documentary work at any given granularity
Description of a Narrative Unit, independent of the Work or textual unit to which it is part. This includes document types, e.g. used to classify additiones to a manuscript.
Description of a concept used as authority list (faith, art element)

sch:rule.sch:report: At least one date must be specified, preferably with a type to indicate the origin of it and evidence
Coordinates should be written as decimal degrees separated by a single space e.g. "14.165289 39.447665" latitude first.

locus must have either an exact reference to a page with @target or a range indicated with @from and @to or either of the two if the other extreme of the range is unknown. Please do not use "unknown" as value.

elementSpec.desc: This was initially inherited from the EpiDoc schema version 8.21. Values for reason and evidence are limited and controlled. This element is used both for transcription and for text editions.Beta maṣāḥǝft Guidelines

valItem.desc: Characters supplied from a parallel version of this text, absent from this one
Characters visible to a previous editor, now lost/unclear due to damage
Restoration of text completely lost from the surface
Text erroneously omitted or skipped by the scribe
Editorial supplement of words subaudible to the native reader
Editorial explanation of oblique text in original
Text restored (e.g. from earlier witness or alternate copy) without specification of current state of this text

elementSpec.desc: This was initially inherited from the EpiDoc schema version 8.21. Beta maṣāḥǝft Guidelines

valItem.desc: space voluntarily left e.g. for later rubrication never accomplished
space voluntarily left e.g. for a potential owner

elementSpec.desc: This was initially inherited from the EpiDoc schema version 8.21. Beta maṣāḥǝft Guidelines

valItem.desc: used to indicate a material loss or a portion of text that is to be hypothesized for material reasons ("it was there!"), but which is lost for loss of the material
a sign, pointing to the place where the text should be added
Text erroneously omitted from the surface by the scribe
Text omitted from the edition by the editor, for whatever reason (brevity, context, language, etc.)
